body:
> If `LogManager` is still in `geode-core` then `log4j-api` is an `api` scoped module. Downstream modules that use `LogManager` need `log4j-api` on the compile class path, which is what `api` scope will do.

log4j-api used to be an implementation dependency. I think @kirklund originally flipped it to API because he was adding new public API that depended on log4j-api, and didn't flip it back to implementation when he made that API internal again.

> log4j-api used to be an implementation dependency. I think @kirklund originally flipped it to API because he was adding new public API that depended on log4j-api, and didn't flip it back to implementation when he made that API internal again.

üëç

I can support that since originally it was `implementation` scoped and internal downstream modules already had to explicitly include `log4j-api` this should be a no-op change. When we do get to the point of spinning out a `geode-logging` module that would be the appropriate time to make it `api` scope.
Looks good now @bschuchardt
Looks good @bschuchardt
I'm not happy about this change. I'm concerned that PMD will no longer be able to inform us if we accidentally make a field mutable, or if we accidentally omit `final`.

I flipped log4j-api from implementation to api when Robert was pairing with me. He explained what it meant and because the other modules are all getting log4j-api Loggers from LogService which lives in geode-core, we determined that it was supposed to be an api dependency. Even though LogService still lives in an internal package, it does still meet the definition of an api dependency instead of implementation.

I think the problem here is that we're trying to saying it's an implementation dependency for users of Geode, but it's an api dependency between Geode modules.

Edit: I still think api is more correct unless we're saying the distinction between api vs implementation is only for users of Geode (instead of between Geode modules) which seems wrong to me. Testing this in https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4080.

I don't want to risk this PR with too many additional changes that I'm unsure of, so I filed https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4079 to test this PR with the geode-core exclusions removed for geode-log4j dependency statements in the gradle files.
I filed https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4080 to test this PR with geode-log4j changed from api dependency to implementation dependency in geode-core.

A class-level @Immutable annotation would be useful iff PMD could leverage it to enforce that all fields are immutable or effectively immutable or annotated @Immutable. 

As it is, this PR seems to be proposing to de-automate a check currently performed by PMD, instead expecting "reviewers from the community should point them out while analysing the PR."  This seems like a step backwards.  Why is it such a bad thing that fields be analyzed and annotated individually?

if we do decide to do this, geode-core needs to depend on this gfsh.jar. Or we can move all the commands  to a commands-module, create a commands.jar, and have geode-core and geode-gfsh both depend on that.

I agree that the docs should match the behavior.

If I were a new developer and saw @Immutable on a class, I would assume[1] it was meant to *enforce* that *all* (especially non-static) members were a) final and b) references to other @Immutable classes (deeply immutable), similar to how other popular @Immutable tags work [2][3].  I would be surprised to discover it actually enforces nothing (actually the reverse, it is a suppression), and very surprised that it actually applies only shallowly and only to statics, especially since its javadoc comment claims it is "broadly similar to the Java Concurrency in Practice annotation".

Static members are not generally thought of as part of the class, just namespaced global variables/constants.  I would much prefer that the only way to mark _static_ references as immutable is one-at-a-time.

The discuss thread from February seems far from settled on how our version of @Immutable should behave at the class level, as the discussion was really centered elsewhere.

In summary, the concept of an _immutable reference_ and an _immutable class_ are two very different things; we really should not be using the same annotation for both.  We should never have overloaded @Immutable, as it has precedent as a class-level-only annotation; we should have picked a different name for our custom Geode annotation for marking effectively-immutable _references_, e.g. @EffectivelyImmutable.

That said, annotations like @Immutable do not actually prescribe how any tooling might or might not use them.  So, as long as classes being marked with @Immutable do in fact follow the generally-accepted semantics of an immutable class, then I guess also using it as a bulk "ignore" flag to work around PMD shortcomings could be tenable for now.

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27101978/what-is-the-advantage-of-annotating-an-immutable-java-class-with-immutable
[2] https://errorprone.info/bugpattern/Immutable
[3] http://jcip.net/annotations/doc/net/jcip/annotations/Immutable.html
will this fix GEODE-6153 as well?
Closing to re-work the solution to address the issues above.

@onichols-pivotal: agreed, and the detailed response is really appreciated üëç.
That said, just one more thing: according to the [original PR description](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3178):

```
Immutable - mark classes or fields that are really immutable as immutable. The pmd rule can ignore these.
```

The above (plus the fact that my class was effectively immutable and annotated with the `@Immutable` annotation) is what made me think I was actually hitting a bug in our custom rule, that's why I opened the ticket and made the changes. Deciding whether we should rename and re-think our current annotations should be addressed through another ticket, and probably after some discussion within the dev list.
If there's not enough consensus to merge this PR I'll just change the rule documentation without touching the actual implementation, at the end of the day it won't kill anyone to annotate multiple fields instead of the class ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇ.

@jdeppe-pivotal I'll modify the build ordering to make sure that `:geode-gfsh:bootJar` is on the default `build` list.

Zip files are nice because the directory info is appended at the **end** of the file which allows for interesting things like prepending an `exe` to the zip. Although this current solution gets to the point of allowing a user to simply do `java -jar geode-gfsh.jar` we could take it one step further and prepend a small exe which essentially does what the `gfsh` script  does now. So it would truly be a single executable. Yes, that would mean separate binaries for each OS.

For inspiration: https://github.com/GeertJohan/go.rice

What happens when we go to v3?  If this is not supposed to be a versioned link, how is v2 any better?

In fact, since dev rest is always under /geode/v1, I prefer to have the dev rest api also be under /geode/v1/api-docs, instead of geode/v2/api-docs. The original swagger api docs for dev rest is in fact under /geode/v1/api-docs, but when Kevin upgraded swagger to use the version 2 of api-docs, he accidentally changed v1 to v2. If we want to roll back to what it was before all the mis-haps, the dev rest api-docs link should remain as "/geode/v1/api-docs"
Looks like there are two +1 reviews, so I'll go ahead and merge this to develop.

IMO it is not ok for the `StaticFieldsMustBeImmutable` rule to ignore classes with the `@Immutable` annotation.

The only purpose I can see, of an `@Immutable` anno, would be to express developer intent similarly to the way `@Override` does. For the expression of intent to be most useful, it would be enforced somehow, e.g. if I mark a class as `@Immutable` but that class has a non-final field, I should get a build-time error.

Mutability of static fields is an issue orthogonal to mutability of the class that contains the fields. Whether or not a class (i.e. its instances) are mutable, it should be viewed as a design bug, if that class has any non-final static field, or any final static field referencing a mutable object type.

So I'm a -1 on this PR as it stands.

I guess I'm in favor of not merging this PR.

Originally I was hoping we could just use `@Immutable` like the JCP annotation - putting it on a class would mean instances of the class are immutable. Then PMD could enforce that static final fields only to refer to `@Immutable` classes. So the fact that you can put `@Immutable` on a static field is really more of a workaround to the limitations of PMD, and maybe the fact that some static fields don't refer to immutable classes that we control.

I agree there is probably more value in using `@Immutable` on a class as documentation that the *instances* of the class are immutable.

@upthewaterspout @Bill @onichols-pivotal @demery-pivotal 

Thanks all for the feedback, instead of modifying the rule's implementation I'll just update its documentation to prevent confusions when the PMD task fails.
I won't open a new PR though, will just update this one instead as the discussion thread is pretty good and might be useful in the future when looking at the ticket üëç.
Cheers.

Yes @onichols-pivotal. Those are dupe tickets.

> I have a question on the discussion thread I would like addressed before reviewing this PR.

I‚Äôve lifted my block based on the email thread outcome. I‚Äôm indifferent to this effort.

> Instead of adding synchronizations and null checks everywhere let's just make that field `final` and change the `close()` method to clear it.

Even butt but I think there is still a race in what to do with calls to this method concurrently with close. The map would be cleared by close but then updated by this method. Having little background in what this is tracking I can‚Äôt say if this is good or bad, it is simply just a case the original code seemed to try to avoid.

I don't think we should be using the state of a collection as an indication of whether the service is open or closed.  There should be other state that we use to avoid creating a new connection and putting it in the connection map if ConnectionTable is closed.

> I don't think we should be using the state of a collection as an indication of whether the service is open or closed. There should be other state that we use to avoid creating a new connection and putting it in the connection map if ConnectionTable is closed.

Couldn't agree more! If you think its safe for connection references that race into the map on close to sit there then this is an easy fix. A simple check if the collection is closed after the put completes could accomplish this. The close itself would empty the map and any race on that operation would get cleared up on the back end after the put by checking for closed state and removing the entry just put.

@metatype currently the create disk-store command with no servers online will fail. I never liked that behavior. I think the rational for it was to make sure the create disk-store would actually work on a real server instead of just putting the info in cluster config and then finding out later when you start a server that some of the disk-store config does not work.
The warning you suggest is much like one we have on the configure pdx command.

@pdxrunner in the use case you describe you say the new option is to allow a disk-store to be created "prior to any server members have joined the cluster". Is this all that is needed? Or do you also need to support creating a disk-store, just in cluster config, when servers have already joined?

@moleske I spent a bunch of time on the StressNewTestOpenJDK11 failure. Looks like GFSH itself is flaky and might take a looooong time to fix. It doesn't look like this test is "fixable" without tearing GFSH apart and putting it back together with bionics.

> @pdxrunner in the use case you describe you say the new option is to allow a disk-store to be created "prior to any server members have joined the cluster". Is this all that is needed? Or do you also need to support creating a disk-store, just in cluster config, when servers have already joined?

No, I don't see a situation where that would be needed. The end result is to have the disk-store created on all servers. After discussing with @metatype  and @jinmeiliao I will rework this PR to provide the behavior that creating a disk-store when there are no servers will not error and will create the configuration.

@jmelchio
@jmelchio

Did you consider using `java.time.*` classes instead of `java.util.Date`? I think the best practice is to use the former unless there is a reason why only `java.util.Date` will do. Jon Skeet has an [interesting article](https://codeblog.jonskeet.uk/2017/04/23/all-about-java-util-date/) about the difference.

If you do switch to a `java.time.*` class, you'll have to be careful about time zones. By default `java.util.Date` uses the system-local time zone which in this case happens to be the same as the time zone in the logs so it works out by happenstance. But if you switch to `java.time.Instant` (basically the analogue to Date), that class defaults to UTC. You'd have to make sure the string version which is output by the command matches the time zone in the logs.

I thought the same improvement but I read in the bookbinder repo that the project was dead. So for me sounds perfect.
BTW, if a new version of Bookbindery gem containing your PR is released, then `geode-book/Gemfile` have to be updated.

I've just found a bug in this PR while working on `GEODE-7283`, so please don't review it yet.
Long story short, the key used to cache the authorization doesn't use the actual method authorized, allowing untrusted methods to be executed.
As an example, `SELECT o.toSring(), o.getClass() FROM /region o` will successfully authorize `o.toString()` (valid method) and store `true` into the cache with a fixed key, causing that all subsequents method invocations for the query (even forbidden ones like `getClass()`) to be wrongly allowed.

I tweaked the language in heap_management.html.md.erb.
I also requested a review from @dschneider-pivotal, who filed the original JIRA ticket in 2016, in hopes that he'll verify that the information is still timely.
